author: Special Correspondent
text:
Three weeks after the announcement of Assembly elections, over 42,000 cases of defacement of property have been reported from the Chennai district. Of these, 20,000 pertain to public property.

The number of complaints has reduced, but defacement of public property continues unabated in many areas.

Usually, many cases of defacement, including setting up of banners, affect pedestrians, motorists and residents on a stretch. “Of the 290 cases of defacement reported on Sunday, 120 involved public buildings,” said an official.

Owing to lack of manpower in each of the 16 constituencies in Chennai district, monitoring political graffiti and banners on footpaths remains a challenge.

The election office began the work on clearing political graffiti, posters and banners after the model code of conduct of elections came into force on March 4.
title: Defacement of public buildings continues
